We have real challenges in terms of unemployment," Kirsten Gillibrand told the round-table discussion, adding that unemployment rates of 15 percent among recently discharged veterans" can not be tolerated." We need to do better in terms of making opportunities available to these veterans so they can get good paying jobs, she added." A lot of veterans don't even know what programs they're eligible for." for an executive who is transitioning out of the CEO role_ and may even be unusual for sitting CEOs, said David Wise, senior principal at management consulting firm Hay Group. But given Eric Schmidt 's success, the board clearly wants to retain his guidance for the next four years. " It's a signal to shareholders that he'll continue to steer the boat," Wise added. Eric Schmidt , 55, is being replaced as Google Inc. 's CEO by co-founder Larry Page.

CEO, was 28 and there were fewer than 200 employees in a small Mountain View office. But after a decade and perhaps some" CEO charm school" for Page, as Laura Macias put it, The training wheels are off, these guys are old enough now to run the company, Kasperzak said. In a blog post announcing the change, Eric Schmidt appears to be saying that the company is looking to be more agile, perhaps seeking that" start-up spark," as some have called

losing engineers frustrated by a shift in the culture that normally happens when a company gets as big as Google is," Seth Harris , technology practice head at Tim Cook Associates, told the E-Commerce Times. Engineers fear the company is not moving fast enough and say it's harder to get time with leaders; many have already made money with Google and see opportunities to move to big private tech firms expected to go public in 12 to 18 months. There has also been talk of tension between Eric Schmidt and Page on competing priorities, Seth Harris added, with Eric Schmidt emphasizing the need to protect margins and Page pushing for more innovation."
